{"agentExecutionMode":"manual","isPanelCollapsed":true,"displayedAnnouncements":[],"conversations":{"51724ecb-b937-4c11-9e58-fbdb0e34470b":{"id":"51724ecb-b937-4c11-9e58-fbdb0e34470b","createdAtIso":"2026-02-26T00:07:35.687Z","lastInteractedAtIso":"2026-02-26T00:07:35.687Z","chatHistory":[],"feedbackStates":{},"toolUseStates":{},"draftExchange":{"request_message":"","rich_text_json_repr":{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph"}]},"mentioned_items":[],"status":"draft"},"requestIds":[],"isPinned":false,"isShareable":false,"extraData":{"isAgentConversation":false,"hasDirtyEdits":false},"personaType":0},"ac95e574-fd2b-4cac-b2e8-60894fb0500b":{"id":"ac95e574-fd2b-4cac-b2e8-60894fb0500b","name":"Push AutoSOC Code to GitHub
","createdAtIso":"2026-02-26T00:07:35.772Z","lastInteractedAtIso":"2026-02-26T00:09:46.184Z","chatHistory":[{"status":"success","request_id":"5f8c8164-1d81-45ad-beee-98933ea9ce61","request_message":"push the code to git hub","rich_text_json_repr":{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"push the code to git hub"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":10,"content":"","token_usage":{"input_tokens":10083,"output_tokens":463,"cache_read_input_tokens":0,"cache_creation_input_tokens":0}},{"id":2,"type":0,"content":"Here's how to push your AutoSOC code to GitHub:

<augment_code_snippet path="scripts/git_setup.sh" mode="EDIT">
```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Initialize git repository
git init

# Add all files
git add .

# Create initial commit
git commit -m "Initial commit: AutoSOC AI-Powered Security Operations Platform"

# Add remote repository (replace with your GitHub repo URL)
git remote add origin https://github.com/achavellir/autosoc.git

# Push to GitHub
git push -u origin main
```
</augment_code_snippet>

**Manual steps:**

1. **Create GitHub repository** at https://github.com/new
 - Name: `autosoc`
 - Keep it private initially (contains API keys in `.env`)

2. **Run these commands:**

<augment_code_snippet path="terminal_commands.sh" mode="EDIT">
```bash
# Initialize and commit
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit: AutoSOC platform"

# Connect to GitHub (use your actual repo URL)
git remote add origin https://github.com/achavellir/autosoc.git

# Push code
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main
```
</augment_code_snippet>

3. **Create `.gitignore`** to exclude sensitive files:

<augment_code_snippet path=".gitignore" mode="EDIT">
```
# Environment variables
.env
.env.local

# Python
__pycache__/
*.pyc
venv/
.pytest_cache/

# Node
node_modules/
.next/
dist/

# Database
*.db
postgres_data/

# IDE
.vscode/
.idea/

# Logs
*.log
```
</augment_code_snippet>

**Important:** Never commit `.env` with real API keys. Use `.env.example` instead.

````bash path=scripts/git_setup.sh mode=EDIT
#!/bin/bash

# Initialize git repository
git init

# Add all files
git add .

# Create initial commit
git commit -m "Initial commit: AutoSOC AI-Powered Security Operations Platform"

# Add remote repository (replace with your GitHub repo URL)
git remote add origin https://github.com/achavellir/autosoc.git

# Push to GitHub
git push -u origin main
````

**Manual steps:**

1. **Create GitHub repository** at https://github.com/new
 - Name: `autosoc`
 - Keep it private initially (contains API keys in `.env`)

2. **Run these commands:**

````bash path=terminal_commands.sh mode=EDIT
# Initialize and commit
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit: AutoSOC platform"

# Connect to GitHub (use your actual repo URL)
git remote add origin https://github.com/achavellir/autosoc.git

# Push code
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main
````

3. **Create `.gitignore`** to exclude sensitive files:

```` path=.gitignore mode=EDIT
# Environment variables
.env
.env.local

# Python
__pycache__/
*.pyc
venv/
.pytest_cache/

# Node
node_modules/
.next/
dist/

# Database
*.db
postgres_data/

# IDE
.vscode/
.idea/

# Logs
*.log
````

**Important:** Never commit `.env` with real API keys. Use `.env.example` instead.

[rejected] main -> main (fetch first)"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"error: failed to push some refs to 'https://github.com/achavellir/autosoc.git'"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"hint: Updates were rejected because the remote contains work that you do not"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"hint: have locally. This is usually caused by another repository pushing to"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"hint: the same ref. If you want to integrate the remote changes, use"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"hint: 'git pull' before pushing again."},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"hint: See the 'Note about fast-forwards' in 'git push --help' for details."}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":10,"content":"","token_usage":{"input_tokens":10836,"output_tokens":373,"cache_read_input_tokens":0,"cache_creation_input_tokens":0}},{"id":2,"type":0,"content":"The remote repository has files that aren't in your local copy. Here are your options:

**Option 1: Pull and merge (recommended if you want to keep remote files)**

<augment_code_snippet path="terminal_commands.sh" mode="EDIT">
```bash
# Pull remote changes first
git pull origin main --allow-unrelated-histories

# Resolve any conflicts if they appear, then push
git push -u origin main
```
</augment_code_snippet>

**Option 2: Force push (overwrites remote - use if remote has only README/LICENSE)**

<augment_code_snippet path="terminal_commands.sh" mode="EDIT">
```bash
# WARNING: This deletes everything on GitHub and replaces with your local code
git push -u origin main --force
```
</augment_code_snippet>

**Option 3: Rebase (cleanest history)**

<augment_code_snippet path="terminal_commands.sh" mode="EDIT">
```bash
# Fetch remote changes
git fetch origin main

# Rebase your commits on top of remote
git rebase origin/main

# Push
git push -u origin main
```
</augment_code_snippet>

**Which to choose?**
- If GitHub repo is empty or just has README → Use **Option 2** (force push)
- If you created the repo with files and want to keep them → Use **Option 1** (pull merge)
- For cleanest history → Use **Option 3** (rebase)

Most likely you want **Option 2** since this appears to be a fresh repo.

Here are your options:

**Option 1: Pull and merge (recommended if you want to keep remote files)**

````bash path=terminal_commands.sh mode=EDIT
# Pull remote changes first
git pull origin main --allow-unrelated-histories

# Resolve any conflicts if they appear, then push
git push -u origin main
````

**Option 2: Force push (overwrites remote - use if remote has only README/LICENSE)**

````bash path=terminal_commands.sh mode=EDIT
# WARNING: This deletes everything on GitHub and replaces with your local code
git push -u origin main --force
````

**Option 3: Rebase (cleanest history)**

````bash path=terminal_commands.sh mode=EDIT
# Fetch remote changes
git fetch origin main

# Rebase your commits on top of remote
git rebase origin/main

# Push
git push -u origin main
````

**Which to choose?**
- If GitHub repo is empty or just has README → Use **Option 2** (force push)
- If you created the repo with files and want to keep them → Use **Option 1** (pull merge)
- For cleanest history → Use **Option 3** (rebase)

Most likely you want **Option 2** since this appears to be a fresh repo.
